items.cardDetailedText: Windows 1.0 was the first graphical user interface (GUI) based operating environment released by Microsoft. It ran as a 16-bit shell on top of MS-DOS, introducing features like a mouse-driven interface, pull-down menus, and scroll bars.
Windows 2.0 introduced overlapping windows, customizable desktops, and better memory management. It was also the first version to include early versions of Word and Excel.

Windows 3.0 was a significant release, featuring a revamped interface with Program Manager and File Manager, and improved multitasking capabilities. It gained widespread popularity and sold millions of copies.
Windows 3.1 introduced TrueType fonts, multimedia support, and improved stability. It also saw the introduction of Minesweeper.
Windows for Workgroups added integrated networking capabilities, allowing users to share files and printers in a workgroup environment.

items.cardSubtitle: First in the Windows NT line for professional use
items.cardDetailedText: Windows NT 3.1 was Microsoft's first 32-bit operating system designed for high-end workstations and servers, focusing on stability, security, and networking.
An update to Windows for Workgroups, offering further improvements to networking and performance.
Windows NT 3.5 brought performance enhancements and broader support for various network protocols.
This version of Windows NT added support for the PowerPC architecture and included minor feature updates.

items.cardSubtitle: Start menu and a new era for Windows
items.cardDetailedText: Windows 95 was a groundbreaking release, introducing the Start button and Taskbar, a 32-bit architecture, and Plug and Play capabilities, making it much easier to use and install hardware.
Windows NT 4.0 merged the user interface of Windows 95 with the robust NT kernel, offering better performance and scalability for business environments.

items.cardSubtitle: Improved web integration and USB support
items.cardDetailedText: Windows 98 focused on improved web integration with Internet Explorer 4.0, better USB support, and enhanced system utilities.
Windows 98 SE was an updated version of Windows 98, including bug fixes, improved hardware support, and Internet Connection Sharing.

Windows 2000 was a business-oriented operating system in the NT family, offering improved security, reliability, and administration tools. It came in Professional, Server, Advanced Server, and Datacenter Server editions.
Windows Me was designed for home users, featuring enhanced multimedia capabilities, System Restore, and Windows Movie Maker. It was the last Windows version based on the Windows 9x kernel.

items.cardSubtitle: Major unified release for home and business
items.cardDetailedText: Windows XP unified the consumer and business lines of Windows, offering a refreshed interface, improved stability, and features like ClearType and Remote Desktop. It became one of the most popular Windows versions.
Windows Server 2003 was a significant update to the server line, providing improved performance, security, and directory services with Active Directory.
This version of Windows XP was released to support 64-bit processors, allowing for larger amounts of RAM and improved performance for demanding applications.
Windows Vista introduced the visually rich Aero glass interface, significant security enhancements with User Account Control (UAC), and improved search capabilities.
Windows Server 2008 built upon Windows Vista's core, offering advanced virtualization features with Hyper-V, improved web server capabilities, and enhanced security.
Windows 7 was highly regarded for its improved performance, stability, and user experience, refining many of the features introduced in Vista and becoming a widely adopted operating system.
Windows Server 2008 R2 was the first server OS from Microsoft to be exclusively 64-bit, bringing further improvements to virtualization, power management, and remote access.
Windows 8 introduced the controversial 'Metro' user interface optimized for touch devices, with a redesigned Start screen and removal of the traditional Start menu.
Windows Server 2012 focused on cloud computing and virtualization, with enhancements to Hyper-V, storage, and networking.

items.cardSubtitle: Return of the Start button and refinements
items.cardDetailedText: Windows 8.1 addressed some criticisms of Windows 8, bringing back a visible Start button and offering more traditional desktop navigation options.
An update to Windows Server 2012, offering further advancements in virtualization, storage, and networking for data centers.

items.cardSubtitle: Universal platform and Start menu return
items.cardDetailedText: Windows 10 aimed to unify the Windows experience across devices, reintroducing a hybrid Start menu, introducing Microsoft Edge, and integrating Cortana.
The first significant feature update for Windows 10, bringing performance improvements, UI refinements, and new features to Edge and Cortana.

items.cardSubtitle: Major feature update with Ink Workspace and improved Edge
items.cardDetailedText: The Anniversary Update brought Windows Ink Workspace, improvements to Cortana and Microsoft Edge, and enhanced security features.

items.cardSubtitle: Cloud-ready server OS with Nano Server
items.cardDetailedText: Windows Server 2016 focused on cloud integration, security, and the introduction of Nano Server, a lightweight deployment option for cloud-native applications.
The Creators Update introduced Paint 3D, improved gaming features with Game Mode, and a new privacy dashboard.

items.cardSubtitle: Fluent Design and OneDrive Files On-Demand
items.cardDetailedText: This update brought the initial elements of Fluent Design, OneDrive Files On-Demand, and improvements to the Photos app.

items.cardSubtitle: Cloud Clipboard and Dark Mode for File Explorer
items.cardDetailedText: The October 2018 Update introduced Cloud Clipboard, a new Snip & Sketch tool, and a dark theme for File Explorer.
Windows Server 2019 focused on hybrid cloud scenarios, improved security, and enhanced support for containers and Linux workloads.
This update brought a new light theme, Windows Sandbox for secure application testing, and a separate search and Cortana experience.
A cumulative update focused on performance improvements, enterprise features, and quality enhancements rather than new major features.

items.cardSubtitle: Improved Cortana and Windows Subsystem for Linux 2
items.cardDetailedText: This update included a new Cortana experience, Windows Subsystem for Linux 2 (WSL 2), and improvements to Virtual Desktops.

items.cardSubtitle: Refined Start menu and Edge integration
items.cardDetailedText: The October 2020 Update brought a theme-aware Start menu, closer integration with the new Chromium-based Microsoft Edge, and improved tablet experience.

items.cardSubtitle: Minor update with performance and security enhancements
items.cardDetailedText: A minor feature update focusing on security, remote access, and quality improvements.

items.cardSubtitle: Advanced multi-layer security and hybrid capabilities
items.cardDetailedText: Windows Server 2022 introduced enhanced multi-layer security, hybrid capabilities with Azure, and flexible application platform features.

items.cardSubtitle: Redesigned interface and Android app support
items.cardDetailedText: Windows 11 brought a significant visual overhaul with a centered Start menu, redesigned Taskbar, and the ability to run Android apps natively.

items.cardSubtitle: Improvements to Start menu, Taskbar, and snap layouts
items.cardDetailedText: The first major feature update for Windows 11, focusing on refinements to the user interface, accessibility, and security features.

items.cardSubtitle: Copilot integration and File Explorer enhancements
items.cardDetailedText: This update introduced Microsoft Copilot (AI assistant), significant improvements to File Explorer, and enhanced backup and restore features.
